Hello, Grant, Calculus is frightening because of Leibniz's notation (symbols) and semantics (connotation). Can Calculus be translated to use algebraic symbols and synonyms (word substitutions where possible), e.g., the slope for derivatives, etc.)

Today's Calculus notations are that of Leibniz; how did Newton's Calculus notation and semantics differ in explaining and presenting his Calculus equation theorems and steps to problem-solving.

The little changes in Leibniz’s words and symbols may not hinder solving a calculus problem. We can save the Leibniz notation from presenting the equations and the method of arriving at the results, yet, not in each line in the resolution process.

When someone can do that to Calculus, maybe we can leave that 16th-17th Century vocabulary behind us; without losing the mode and methods of reaching the answers.

Note how the English language has changed with time, both spoken and written from the 12th century through this day. We do not talk nor write with the minimum words as they did. Why should we retain their mathematical semantics?

Although I am astonished and hold the work of Grant of incredibly high value, there is some criticism I should like to propose and some warnings to those viewing this channel and this particular series, especially those who were influenced by Grant (just like myself some time ago) to do the Mathematics. I shall begin with the warnings. All over the comment section I have observed numerous comments saying that, say “why isn’t maths being taught this way at school?” or “your videos have inspired me to go in for maths, thank you!” etc.. I should warn you, that it is quite easy to become arrogant. Let me expand upon that. Say, you have just finished this series (or this video), and from observing the beautiful intuitive constructs at play and seeing certain relations, you may start to feel as if you already know the subject, as though you already know the subtleties and by appealing to intuition anything, even the hardest problem, can be resolved. The harsh truth is that it is not even remotely so. Pick any calculus textbook after watching this series, open, say, a section on the mean value theorem of the differential calculus, or certain integration problems, or maybe just the limits section with all of the definitions and propositions etc. and open the problem set included, without reviewing the theory written beforehand. You will be surprised that if the texbook is decent enough (pick, for instance, Richard Courant’s “Differential and Integral Calculus”), then you will not be able to solve even a third of those. Can you prove, for example, that using L’Hopital’s rule to find the limit of f(x) = sin(x)/x as x tends to 0 is considered to be the mathematical equivalent of committing a crime? When I first watched this series, I could not, and I was getting laughed upon for that. You see, “skipping” the formalisms and definitions, heading straight for the picturesque intuition and calling it a day is wrong. For formalisms unravel more information than you could possibly hope to with intuition, plus they allow you to (a) see the “greater picture” of the mathematical principles at play; (b) exclude the flaws that emerge from an intuitive understanding of the concepts. For those who go in for mathematics this later becomes a devastating disappointment and they find out that they have actually been led astray all the time, discouraging them from going further into the immensely beautiful field that is Mathematics, simply because they thought that only bad teachers jump into formalisms and that intuition is the sole thing that matters.

Remember this: A good Mathematics teacher reveals the intuition behind the concepts. An excellent teacher intertwines it with formalism and abstraction, while not losing the intuition from sight, simply expanding upon it greatly.

As regards the criticism I mentioned: Grant (I hope I am not insulting you by referring to you directly by your name, I apologise if that is so), I think that you should make more remarks regarding the fact that there is much more information than that which you introduce. As far as I can remember, at the very start of the series, you mentioned that very briefly, but soon it devolved into phrases such as “If you know what the word “approach” means, you already know what the limit is”, which is just plain wrong, even though you made a little remark about epsilon-delta arguments, which is still not enough in the slightest. I should like to suggest that you make certain textbook recommendations if not on particular concepts, but at least upon that branch of Mathematics as a whole. It is needed in order (a) that students do not get confused and discouraged when they hit their forehead at the formalism and rigour of the Mathematics; (b) to make your course more “complete”, if you can put it this way. If the latter is not your general aim, then, as I have already said, I believe you should make short glimpses of the “reality” of Mathematics, such as “I hope I have provided you with all the necessary intuition. This intuition, though beautiful and useful in and of itself, is almost nothing like what you will encounter “in the wild”, that being…”, for instance.

Thank you!

I have a different visualisation of this. That rotating line around the circle, it wipes the area of the circle. Consider instead, a line wiping though the area of a rectangle (r x 2pi). Now if you hold one end of the line at 0, and only advance the other end, it wipes a triangle (area/2), and each relative point of the line has covered the same distance as the one that rotates around the circle. One end travels 0, the other 2pi.

Many of the comments ask why can't teachers and professors teach this well. The answer is that most people think visually far better than abstractly. The better you can display math visually, the better you will teach the subject to most people. Even in 2021 it's impossible for a teacher at a whiteboard to hand draw diagrams that can come close to matching the detailed animation put into these excellent videos. Unless a high school or college wished to purchase the rights to videos like this as a learning aid, then they'll leave it up to the teacher and his hand drawn diagrams. We now have the technology to produce superb animations in far less time for far less cost than ever before in history. It's about time that learning institutions abandon some of the ancient methods of teaching and take advantage of this technology.

I was terrible at school mathematics, but had a sound conceptual understanding of most other subjects. I assumed maths was like music, and I just happened to be tone deaf. This video suggests the error was not with me (who simply wanted to know "why?"), but teachers who applied solutions to problems so longstanding, they'd forgotten they were ever problems at all - if they ever knew. This feeling was compounded by kids who were good at maths, and had no obvious theoretical understanding they could, or would, impart to the rest of us. If that wasn't enough, kids who were good at the subject got the best teachers, the middling ones got ok maths teachers, and the rest (like me) had teachers who showed no sign of understand further than the next chapter in the book, and cared even less.

As I got older and met people who performed well in maths exams (like my wife and kids), I came to realise they assessed a question and solved it with Patch A or whatever looked most likely, but still couldn't answer my "but why!" If I'd had access to videos like this many decades ago, mathematics would not have been the giant leap from the arithmetic I was pretty good at. Thanks for posting!

When I was 15 my elder brotheralready had finished his engineering degree. He straight up started teaching me calculus as if it's something I would absolutely need at every step in life.

Several years later I was once studying with this girl in first year of my engineering and she was trying 'learn' double and triple integrals. She was one of the toppers of her class with consistent good grades. I let her study on her own but after a while I decided to try explaining the concept of area under a curve in a similar way he does in this video. I had no expectations for her to understand considering she probably preferred memorizing. I faintly remember how amazed she was after she understood the 'why this works' from this video.

We remained best friends for years after that day, haven't talked to her in many years now.

But the bottom line is my brother was teaching me calculus not because it would be useful because he knew me and that how much I would love it. In my opinion it's no different from introducing sport, music or chess etc to your younger kids. Sometimes you know they'll just enjoy learning it.

The reason so many people like these videos is that this guy understands that not everyone learns the same way.   Some people learn by being told how to do something (hearing).  Some people learn by watching, and some by doing.   Here you get the first two.  He also does something else that is important.   He ties the mathematical concepts to something practical that most people understand.   (The example I always used to teach integrals and derivatives is an accelerating car.   A constant acceleration yields a linearly changing velocity and a quadratically varying distance.   You can work it in either direction.  Given any one parameter's distribution with time you can derive the other two.)   These videos are put together by a great teacher.

See the comment below first. Now on to the area of a square and area of a circle. Do you think we will find the exact same ratio. And can write it so a 5 year old can see it? The answer is yes it is that simple.

They teach the area of a square is length times width. The area of a square is diameter times diameter. Or d x d. Now remember the ratio of a circle to a square? It is 3.14 to 4. So what is that ratio? It is 3.14 divided by 4 or .785. (3.14/4 = .785).

So calculate the circle's area exactly the same way as the square. Diameter times diameter times .785. Or (d x d x .785). When you calculate the square and circle differently you lose the fact that they are related, they have the constant ratio of 3.14 to 4. So pi becomes very easy to see.

Here's a way to think about the representation at 14:44. I've been confused about why dx approaches zero but x does not even though the AREAS of all three rectangles approach zero at the same rate. As x approaches zero, the rectangles representing the change in x begin to look like line segments. The square representing dx on the other hand approaches a point. A line segment may not have area, but it does have length and that can be measured. A point is non dimensional and so is TRULY zero in all three dimensions. So as you approach zero, dx approaches zero and x approaches the length of the line segment that it approaches. This helped me understand why even though the AREA of all three rectangles approach zero, dx is the only element that actually approaches zero itself.
THank you and a big hanks to all the people who helped in this video.

Not long ago I got prompted with the question "calculate the are below this curve". I had no idea about calculus at all, but I wanted to solve it.
To me what seemed like an obvious solution I can solve was this:
Just calculate the value of f(x), which is the curve, with n evenly spaced values. Let's say n is 10. If I needed the area from x = 0 to x = 5, then I would calculate f(0.5), f(1.0), f(1.5) ... f(5.0).
Since when I imagined the graph of it, it seemed to me that if I make these into rectangles, that would be a close enough approximation of the area, and since all of them are the same with, I can just add them together then multiply them with it.
So: ( f(0.5) + f(1.0) + f(1.5) + ... + f(5.0) ) * ( 5 / 10 ) would give me a pretty good approximation, and I could calculate it by hand in a reasonable time.

Seeing this video, now I think what I did is pretty close to the "proper solution", or at least this would be the base concept for it, probably without this much of approximation :P
Man, I feel clever for doing it, even though in this state it's just a crappy solution that just happens to be working xD

Area Problem
1. If you want to find the area of a circle, you can split it up into concentric circles. Each concentric circle has an area of 2pir * a difference in radius. The smaller you make that difference in radius, the more accurate your approximation. If you put this concept on graph with r as the x axis and 2pi(r) as the y axis, then adding up all of those rectangles gives you the area of a triangle.
2. The question is "how can we find the area of a generic curve". Here's what we figured - a concept known as the fundamental theorem of calculus. We can write dA = dx * x^2 which means that the ratio of a tiny nudge in A to a tiny nudge in x is equal to the function value at that point. This means that our slope measures the amount that our area is changing.

Three "Eureka" moments in math:

1. Getting the conceptual understanding of the math you are doing (being able to explain the math without over relying on equations and formulae), another to say that is to be able to extract out the "essence" of math. This stage is crucial for convincing yourself on the mathematical facts and relationships demonstrated.
2. Starting from scratch, guided with physical/mathematical motivations to experience the process of discovering (reinventing) the mathematics one is doing. [This suddenly makes everything you do about that area of math to be "meaningful"]
3. Being able to spot the same math to emerge in different areas/context via different forms, and hence being able to generalise the idea. [The original idea hence become more fruitful and rich]

I was teaching my 5 year old daughter simple addition. And I asked 17 + 2 and she calculated it is 19. And then I asked
Me: "How many 10s in 17?"
She: "1"
Me: "How many 10s in 2?"
She: "0"
Me: How many 10s in 19, our result of the addition?"
She: "1"
Me: "See the 10s adds up correctly too"
She: "OK"

And then I showed the 1s adds up too (basically 7 + 2 = 9)

Me: Now what is 17+4
She: 21 (after a long finger calculation and with help as she normally forgets the number after 19)
Me: How many 10s in 17?
She: 1
Me: How many 10s in 4?
She: 0
Me: So how many 10s in total
She: 1 + 0 = 1 (I wrote 10s => 1)
Me: How many 1s in 17?
She: 7
Me: How many 1s in 4?
She: 4
Me: And 7 + 4?
She: 11 (I wrote 1s => 11)
Me: But now 10s=>1 and 1s=>11. It is not the 10s and 1s in the actual answer 21. Did we do something wrong?
She: Oh
Me: See the 11 has one extra 10s. That could be it? (and bit more explanation)
She: Wow. This is difficult and very nice at the same time
I cried a little.

Very nice animations, but isn't it shifting the goalposts a little to say "why is it that Pi times the radius squared gives you the area of a circle? Why, simply because we can calculate the area of the smaller circles comprising it, because we know that Pi times their radius doubled gives us their circumference!" I mean, if the answer to "why area?" is just "circumference" then doesn't the question become "why circumference?" Why is the former worth pondering deeply about, but the latter is something we should just still take as a rule we memorized in grade school? Wasn't the point of the overall question to figure out why pi works the way it does, to really understand it instead of just using rote memorization? At 5:24 , How do you know the concentric circumferences form a straight line when you stack them up side by side? Each subsequent circle is 2*pi*dr longer than the previous one. Since thickness dr is constant throughout this, so is the angle of elevation between two subsequent slices. This makes the line connecting the tip of the slices straight and gives us a nice triangle to get our formula :)

Engineering student here. Every math class I've taken from elementary to high school was all about (not necessarily all the time but a lot of the times), here is the method and here is how you do it, rather than giving beautiful mathematical examples that are fascinating and mind blowing just how you animated. It's amazing what even a maths student at a decent proficiency level still learn and I am glad I found this channel because I am learning again and it has allowed me to see the beauty in mathematics.

It's really sad that schools don't start teaching this way more because a lot of students tend to ask the question of "what is the point of all of this?" (usually in secondary/middle school in the UK) when I was in school. And I don't blame them because teachers don't really make students see how things work and derived as beautifully as this. If this was a UK secondary school the teacher would just be like A = pi*r^2 for the exam and that's it (and for A levels). But if they allowed students to see how it was found using calculus or some other method, than they could most likely see and starting thing about a wider implication in the applications and usage of calculus.

One thing that was not obvious to me from your visual explanation, is that when you take all those concentric rings and put them all side by side on a graph, they line up in a perfectly straight line. But how can you assume they make a straight line and not some curve?

So I reasoned it like this: The length is 2.pi.r, which is a linear function of r, which is a straight line. And as you sweep along R, the length is a constant 2.pi times that.

At my old job, they just used a scale and measured the weight of the wood, and subtracted that from the understanding of a rectangular prism of the wood before it was cut. Thats calculus with elementary school math tools.

This is a fantastic lesson. It is interesting that he starts with areas and integrals. All calculus course start with differentials followed by integration. This approach, with its simple clear explanations building up from basic math gives the student a clear explanation of the processes involved. It really accomplishes its goal of presenting the material so that the student says, "I could have invented Calculus."

I have never seen anyone start with the circle and turn the areas into small rectangles before. It is a great starting place, and accomplishes multiple goals. The students learn the thought processes used to develop mathematics in general and Calculus specifically. They gain deeper insights into how the integral is developed and it relation to real world scenarios. And they learn why the formula for the area of circle looks like it does as an added bonus.

Understanding why the calculations are done the way are and how they relate to real world problems give the student the deep understanding of Calculus so often lacking in traditional classrooms where the teacher just drones on about equations and applications.

I wish math teachers did better jobs of teaching calculus in this manner because it would have made my job of teaching Physics so much easier. As it was, I had to teach Calculus before and alongside Physics. I had a policy of teaching the students how the equations they used were derived and how they related to the real world situations they described. Just like this video, I started with simple concepts and built on them until we arrived at the result we wanted. It was more about the process and understanding of fundamental concepts than the final answer.

I have not seen any other episodes, but if they are all like this, I would recommend using this series in place of the distance learning now going on during the Covid-19 crisis.

Wayne Adams
B.S. Chemistry (ACS Certified)
M.S, Physics
R&D Chemist 9 yrs.
Physics Instructor 33 yrs.

I know I'm a little late, but I just found this. And decades ago, in rec.humor.funny newsgroup, one of the "funniest" math jokes were posted. It's funny because when starting out in calculus and doing integral problems, you always had to add the "+ C" Then we all started dropping it. With that background, here's the joke from rec.humor.funny

Two mathematicians were having dinner in a restaurant, arguing about the average mathematical knowledge of the American public. One mathematician claimed that this average was woefully inadequate, the other maintained that it was surprisingly high.
"I'll tell you what," said the cynic, "ask that waitress a simple math question. If she gets it right, I'll pick up dinner. If not, you do." He then excused himself to visit the men's room, and the other called the waitress over.
"When my friend comes back," he told her, "I'm going to ask you a question, and I want you to respond `one third x cubed.' There's twenty bucks in it for you." She agreed.
The cynic returned from the bathroom and called the waitress over. "The food was wonderful, thank you," the mathematician started. "Incidentally, do you know what the integral of x squared is?"
The waitress looked pensive; almost pained. She looked around the room, at her feet, made gurgling noises, and finally said, "Um, one third x cubed?"
So the cynic paid the check. The waitress wheeled around, walked a few paces away, looked back at the two men, and muttered under her breath, "...plus a constant."

There is another way to understand the "circle area" formula that I think I just "invented". Considering two points A and B on the circle, and these points are very close together. Thus, we can consider the circle as the combination of a huge amount of this type of triangle lay adjacent. Back to A and B, let's denote C as the midpoint of AB. Because A and B are very super ultra ultimate immensely close, we can say that OA=OB=OC=R. So, the area of OAB = 0.5*R*(AB). So the area of the circle is Soab * (the number of triangles - let's denote as n). In addition, the circle length is 2*pi*R, and n*AB is approximately 2*pi*R.  So, we can re-write the area as 0.5*R*((2*pi*R)/n)*n = pi*R*R.

The beautiful argument in Python:

#Area of a circle with radius 25
import math
import numpy as np
rad = 25
itt = 0.001
a = 0
for i in np.arange(itt,rad+itt,itt):
a += (2*math.pi*i)*itt
print("The area of circle with radius ",rad," is= ", a)

The intro of trying to find the area of a circle by slicing it into concentric rings, then standing up these rectangles under a graph seems incredibly convoluted. Maybe that’s the stepping stone to graphing, but it’s not the most direct way to approximate the area of a circle. ⭕️

I haven’t studied math in years, and never even finish applied math in high school. But if I were an early mathematician and wanted to know the approximate area of a circle, I would do it this way.

1) Take a piece of string, wrap it around the circle and mark the string where it made a full circle.
2) Stretch the string into a straight line.
3) Measure the beginning and end of the line and divide by 4.
4) Then take this number and multiply it by itself. That’s the area converted from a circle to square so can measure it.

There you have it.

You can do something similar to find the volume of a jug or other oddly shaped container.

Just construct a cube with measurement markings on it. Pour the contents of the jug or cylinder into the cube, and there you have your answer.

Calculus for me came alive when I looked at the differences between squares and realized the diffs of the diffs was 2.  Then I looked at cubes and found that the diffs of the diffs of the diffs was 6.  For 4th-powers, the 4th diffs were 24.  Essentially, I was seeing the simplest practical example of the Nth derivative of X^n being n! .  Didn't realize it at the age of 11, but later on was fascinated by the formulae related to what I had "discovered".

A few years ago, I got a bit bored, so tried my hand at deriving the formula for the area of a circle. I got there by slicing it into smaller and smaller pie sections where each pie section approached a right-angled triangle with the short side being some fraction of the circumference, and the long side being the radius (radius and hypotenuse would approach equality as the angle got smaller and smaller too). So the area of the triangles would be 1/2(r.((pi.2r)/x)).x with x being the number of slices. Simplified out it became pi.r^2 :D


Just this week I got bored again... and started wondering how pi got calculated - had some fun working that one out!!! Got to pi=(360/x).sin(x/2) with it getting more accurate as x approaches 0 :D


Sure, I could've just googled them, but it was so rewarding to have that AHA! moment when I figured it out! I'd encourage everyone to try to figure things out themselves every once in a while, because that is a very special feeling!

Grant,
Damn but your expressive little blue Pi's are intelligently done!
I think maybe you should be in the running for a Pulitzer in cartooning for them!
I also think your Einstein quote, to the effect that the cultic "math and reality are identical" is ver-ree apropos. When I first read Eugene Wigner's paper, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Unreasonable_Effectiveness_of_Mathematics_in_the_Natural_Sciences, I thought it must be a bad translation from the Hungarian.
It turns out he was serious. Ugh! There are a whole slew of things wrong with it, among other things that for every mathematical construct suggesting a reality there a bunch of other ones with different implications. I think the Big One, though, is that most of the mathematics Wigner celebrates takes the form of differential equations, and these are hypotheses, not conclusions. Even their solutions are mere suggestions, not statements about reality.
The Wiki entry on Wigner's paper does him a great favour, suggesting a tentativeness that I don't see in the original; to my mind, the paper is emphatically wrong, and your Einstein quote gets it right.

The basic concept of calculus is any function can be approximated to a line segment in the vicinity of any value of x. This holds true provided the departure from x is very small. For the thus produced line segment the gradient can be found easily by evaluating the change in y devided by the change in x. The gradient function that is derived in this way is known as the derivative function.

Integration, on the other hand, is the reverse process of differentiation. This means, from a given derivative function, the original undifferentiated function is found. Some functions have no analytical integral.

The area under a curve in two dimentions is an example evaluation of integration. An integral function is evaluated for a given interval. This kind of integration often results in a plain numerical answer, provided the original function does not have parameters.

A yet another area of calculus is differential calculus. This deals with the expression and solution of equations involving differentials like dY/dx and higher order differentials.

35 years ago I took my Maths A Level and failed it (A Levels in the UK are the exams you take at 18). The teacher had started the course, on calculus, by telling us he was going to teach us what we needed to know to pass the exam and would not bother with any of the "why it works", and he was true to his word. The problem is I just cannot learn that way. I think it was a terrible way to teach. After two years of study I did not understand calculus beyond knowing some of the rules ("how to differentiate", "how to integrate") and I remember being even unable to revise my notes because I had no idea what was going on. I deservedly failed the exam.

A few years later, now in the workplace, in my spare time, just to prove I wasn't that stupid, I learned the basics of calculus from a book which actually explained it.

I have serious doubts about the whole efficacy of standard schooling. I spent so many years of my young life there and learned so little. I have learned so much since, just in my spare time. I honestly believe that private study with a video like this is a far better way to learn. Sure, now we have video on demand and easy production of animations by individuals, but an animation like this could have been done quite cheaply even in the 80s, and if they had given me these videos on VHS tape and sent me home to watch them I swear I could have passed that exam after just a few weeks study.

Caveat: the videos would have to be produced by as good a teacher as 3Blue1Brown of course. As I recall, most educational media back then was chronically bad too.

Another way I thought of estimating the area of circle is sum of small quadrants.
A quadrant is roughly a triangle of length r, and base dr. So its area is 1/2 * r * dr.
The total area of the circle is the sum of all quadrants.

The circumference of a circle can be divided into these many quadrants of base dr: 2*pi*r/dr.
Thus the total are of the circle is the area of a quadrant * the number of quadrants, which is
(1/2*r*dr) * (2*pi*r/dr) => pi*r^2

Video Summary by one of my student:

The video's aim is to give us a gist of what calculus really is. It wants us to look deeper into problems, think about them, and come up with different ways to solve them. Also, if we're taught concepts like derivatives and integrals, how we would solve them without the already taught formulae. How we would even try different methods, as if we ourselves were mathematicians.So it starts with the simple concept of finding the area of a circle. We can come up with different methods of finding it, but one example is cutting the circle into many concentric rings and labelling the thicknesses as 'dr'. Now, when we lay down one ring, it'll almost look like a rectangle. We can only assume this because we consider the trapeziums to be very very thin. Obviously, their lengths will be the corresponding circumferences 2πr (their radii are varying). Area of each rectangle is then 2πrdr. It's important to know that even though it's not entirely accurate, the accuracy increases as dr decreases. Now when f we place all the strips on a graph with their radius lengths on the X axis and their lengths (2πr) on the Y axis and slope 2π. Now we usually see the area under the graph to calculate all the areas of the strips. This is a triangle.It comes out to be πr^2. Hence its a problem where we find the sum of many small values where the limit (here, dr) approaches 0. This is integration, and it's found by the area under the graph. Similarly for other more complex graphs (example, for finding integral of x^2, we assume there is tiny increase in area 'dA' with the change in X axis as dx and Y axis as x^2 and then take area under graph.) Here, dA/dx is derivative of Area A. So, we come to the fundamental theorem of Calculus that Integral and Derivatives are, in a way, inverses of each other. We face day to day problems and practical situations where the use of calculus is essential.

Also, if you think of just cutting a circle along its radius, and "unwrapping" it into the shape of a rectangle, the base of that rectangle is the circumference, and the height of the rectangle is the radius. Therefore, the area is just radius times circumference. Because pi is defined as the ratio of the circumference to the radius, you can do the following: C*R = (C/R)*R^2 = (pi)R^2. The triangle thing is probably a better way of thinking about it, though.

If anyone got confused at 5:37 like me about why the approximation keeps getting better, understand that it's because you have to chop off lesser and lesser of that trapezoid's area as they get smaller.

5:29 I think 3Blue1Brown moved a bit fast from ½ × 3⋅2π⋅3 and to π3² ... It was hard for me to understand why it suddenly became something else without an explanation. So I looked into it, and I think I found a way to solve it through the method of cancellation:

The area of a rectangle is base times height (b⋅h). The area is the same, only halved (½ × b⋅h). Given a base equal to the radius (𝑟) of the circle, where 𝑟 = 3, and a height that is 2π⋅𝑟, then we can do ½ × 3⋅2π⋅3

We can simplify this by the Cancellation Method. First off make sure each side is like: ½ × 1/(3)(2π⋅3)
Then we simply cancel like terms from both sides: (1-1)/(2-2) × (1-1)(3)((2-2)π⋅3)
And we're left with 3⋅π⋅3, or rather π3²

It took watching this twice to understand why you used the "approximate rectangle" bit about dx and the area of a circle. I seem to get very distracted when I intuitively pick up on problems within an argument intended to teach a simplified example. The entire first time I watched the video I was distracted by the thought, "both ends of the cut rectangle are equal. One end can be cut matched to the other and made into an exact rectangle." All that talk about 'approximation' didn't make sense to me. I followed the logic just fine but failed to connect with the underlying perspective.
The second time watching this video I connected the example of the car's velocity/distance curve and I finally understand the need for approximating the size of dx. This kind of situation has been a challenge for me in the past when I was in school.
Intuitively, I see the area of a circle to triangle issue differently. Just view the radius of a circle as the base of a triangle. Then look at the circumference as the height, but with some posture issues. Once the height gets stood up straight you have your triangle untwisted. It's not so easy to take that intuitive understanding and backtrack to one proposed as an approximation.
On a Myers-Briggs test I tend to score very high percentages on the intuitive scale but only average for the "thinking" aspect. I always test as an INTJ. Once I get past algebra I seem to struggle.
I don't mean to be critical of another Content Creator, and writing this is probably totally pointless as it's inevitably lost in the sea of comments. I really appreciate someone that takes such an intuitive approach to teaching. I don't know how you could address a problem like intuitive 'holes' within teaching methodology, but I've always found them challenging. Perhaps I will be able to better understand by rewatching your content several times.
February 26th 2014 I was hit by a car while commuting to work on a bicycle. Now I'm partially disabled. At 33 I am forced to use my mind to get by instead of muscles but it is particularly difficult to take on these subjects later in life. I need to add new tools to my mental toolbox. I spent far too many years learning about tools in a metal tool box. I guess I've been one 'n' short of a full box most of my life. Thanks for the upload.
-Jake

the way i found pi(r^2) was different than graphing and using the triangle
i took the rectangle loops and got all of their areas for a circle where its circumference is known to be 6.28.

This became the expression (~3.14(r^2) * dr) = the area of (1) rectangle.
then, i made the expression consider how many rectangles there were, by dividing 1/dr i got the number of rectangles
1/dr = h
(h is a random variable to express that
so the end expression would be
(3.14(r^2) * dr) * (1/dr)
or
(3.14(r^2) * dr) * h

either way, the part where I multiplied dr by 3.14(r^2) and h could cancel each other out.
leaving me with 3.14(r^2)

One of my favourite little bits of trivia about calculus is that while the first principles are taught in terms of limits it was originally created using infitessimals, which aren't really considered a "real" thing these days, having had their utility replaced by limits. So one of the core concepts used to teach the fundamental way calculus works didn't exist in its current form when calculus was created, which I think is pretty impressive on the part of mathematicians like Newton and Leibnitz.

I have a theory
my theory is π=0
a perimeter is the length of the sides of a shape. a circumference is the length of the outer layer of a circle. now I will start with my theory. the formula of square is 4s. now if you add another side but still want to remain it's perimeter you will then shorten the length of the side, let say we have square its side is 10 the perimeter would be 40, now we add another but still want to remain the perimeter 40 the formula would be 5n=40, n=40/5, n=8 now the length of the side is 8. if we keep on doing this and we reach 100 sides the polygon would now be closer to be being a circle but it is still not a circle. now if we continue on and let's say we reach infinity then the length of the sides will be 0 because if you add more side the length of it will decrease. now the formula would be I•0, I is infinty. earlier we said that the circumference is the length of the outer layer of the circle and the perimeter is also the length of all the side of a shape so basically saying circumference=perimeter.
now to find the circumference of a circle the formula we use is 2πr. so now 2πr=I•0 because of what we said earlier circumference=perimeter. now we want to make pie be alone so now we divide 2r on both side,
2πr/2r=I•0/2r, now π is now alone π=I•0/2r. now we multiply infinite to 0, it is said that anything multiplied by zero will be zero so what we have left is π=0/2r and if we divide 0 by 2r then it would be 0 so π=0 and this is where I end my theory thanks for reading and what do you think

For the first proof at the beginning, I was thinking about how to add some more so-called "rigor." Mainly, I have trouble believing that the concentric circle thing is 2pi*r*dr. In the event that someone else is having these thoughts, here's a nice supplement argument:

So yeah, it appears to be a trapezoid, but that's not all. Our approximation (while it does get closer) is always less than the actual area. (You can see this in the ending graph so 2pi*r: the bars are always under the graph.) The natural analog to this is to consider the r so that it's always just above the graph. So, while we chose the r to be 0.1, 0.2, ..., 3, we will now choose r' to be 0, 0.1, 0.2, ..., 2.9. Using much the same argument, we can show that this one will also converge to pi*r^2 for the area. Because one was always bigger and the other was always smaller, we can conclude that at infinity both have the same area, and whatever's in between (the actual circle), must also converge to pi*r^2.

(Rigor for the last step is the Squeeze Theorem.)

As deputy sergeant of the nitpick police, a comment: at 11:38 the variable x is a bit overloaded, isn't it? It's being used both as the variable in the definition of the parabola, x^2, and the input to the area function, A(x). This might be a problem because the function A is being thought of as mapping a given x to a number which is the area under the graph of y=t^2 (using t as a dummy variable, we don't mean x here) from 0 to x. I only mention this because a dummy variable also shows up when you write the fundamental theorem in the usual way.

It is interesting how you said at the end of findind area of a circle formula [paraphrasing] " lets find out why did that work?"....I immediately thought:
What do we mean by "it worked"?

Bare with me here...
We only have an argument that led us to the same formula that someone else ALSO obtained. So..by "it worked" we simply mean that it agrees with someone elses formula. My point here is: How does the first person to reach the formula...or a person that doesnt know any formula for the area of the circle to compare with...knows that whatever they obtained is in fact the right answer? How can you be sure that you are right when you have nothing to compare with?

The answer to those question is also an important part of discpvering new mathematics. It also points to how education techniques sometimes fail to teach what it is that can make you confident about what you discover.
Looking forward to precise definition of limits!

hello, i am working on a force based physics engine, and have trouble with spring dampening combined with friction of large interacting particle systems in 2D.

i have a grid of particles,
i calculate the force of the springs on every diagonal, horizontal and vertical. it is dependent on the position and the velocity of the particles and is computed separately for synchronization issues. i cannot write it mathematically but here is the algorithm:

//Springs
float2 springforce = (float2)(0, 0);
for (int i = 0; i < 8; ++i) { // in each available direction (horizontal, diagonal, vertical)
const int2 curmap = vecmap[i];
uint lastpos = getXid(xid, curmap, 0, width);
for (int l = 1; (springs[lastpos] & map[i]) != 0; l++) {//linear and diagonal rigidity beams
const uint newpos = getXid(xid, curmap, l, width);
lastpos = newpos;

const float2 displacement = pos[newpos] - pos[xid];
const float2 force = 200000 * ((length(displacement) / l - veclength[i]) * normalize(displacement));
const float2 drag = 100 * ((vel[newpos] - vel[xid]) / l);
springforce += force + drag;
}
}

forces[xid] = springforce;

a float2 is a two part vector

i then apply standard forces but with impulses. i would like to change it to a force based formula:

float mass = masses[xid];
if (mass == 0 || strength[xid] == 0 || xid >= size)
return;
//flooding
mass *= 0.08;
//Buoyancy
const float2 position = pos[xid];
const float waterHeight = water(position.x, dimensions, time);
const float density = getDensity(position.y, waterHeight);
const float2 buoyantForce = (float2)(0, getBuoyancy(density));

vel[xid] += ((buoyantForce + forces[xid]) / mass + (float2)(0, -9.81)) * delta; // forces[xid] is the previous springforce
//Drag
const float velocitySq = lengthSq(vel[xid]);
const float velocity = native_sqrt(velocitySq);
const float2 velocityVec = normalize(vel[xid]);
const float drag = velocitySq * 0.5 * density;
const float altdrag = velocity * delta * mass;
const float2 dragforce = velocityVec * drag;

vel[xid] -= dragforce / mass * delta;
pos[xid] += vel[xid] * delta;

if you have any insight or somewhere to direct me I would be happy. please note i cannot iterate over all other particles as the simulation has to simulate at least 100k particles on an average graphics card. each formula must be calculated independently on each particle because of the use of OpenCL 1.0.

even approximations are useful. The simulation becomes unstable with high buoyancy or high stress, and causes the particle system to overflow arithmetically (it explodes into nan velocities). I cannot use double floating points for performance reasons.

I have been waiting for someone to explain math (specifically Calculus) as an art. Slowly explaining the beauty behind the bigger picture and showing me how the abstract is in reality, simply natural. For the first time someone (you) inspired me about math, and I can almost feel your appreciation for it.

I always thought I was terrible at math. But over the last few years, I've realized that I was just so disillusioned by ineffective teachers and terrible curricula (e.g. I was one of the guinea pigs for "Touch Math" in kindergarten through second grade. If you're not familiar with that approach and want to taste bile in the back of your throat, look it up sometime. Even today, my hometown friends and I get into long diatribes about how long it took to un-learn that crap.)

This had some profound consequences on the course of my education, leading me to write off STEM fields entirely when I settled on a major. So, despite being a insufferable (until something breaks) computerphile and science fanboy for as long as I can remember, the fundamental concepts underlying both remained a mystery.

Then I stumbled upon Numberphile a few years ago and things started making more sense. Numberphile led to Sixty Symbols, led to Computerphile, led to Standup Maths, led to Mathologer, and that led me to your channel. Appreciation became fascination and finally, at 27 and with a largely useless Liberal Arts BA, the language of the universe makes sense. It's just unfortunate that it took this long before excellent, impassioned communicators like yourself were on my radar.

tl;dr: Thank you, Grant. I've been waiting for a good high-level demystification of calculus for a while; can't wait to see more. And, once I get out of unemployment limbo, you'll definitely be getting a new Patron.

There is a hidden supposition in the process of finding the area of a circle. You supposed that lengths of those circular segments must increase linearly. (Of course they are, because the formula for the length of a segment is l=2pr so it is linear with respect to r.) But you didn't underline this fact. So your proof is based on a (hidden) supposition.

2:14
(1) slice the circle like a pizza, into segments
(2) re-arrange those pieces top-to-tail, top-to-tail, .... so it looks like a (lumpy) rectangle/parallelogram
(3) the base of the rectangle/parallelogram is half the circumference (ie it's pi*r)
(4) the height of the rectangle is r
(5) so the area of the circle is pi*r*r = pr*r^2
This is the start of something beautiful :D
